We don’t want to make mistakes when we speak in a public gathering. Whatever the cause of your public speaking anxiety, you can overcome it with these five steps:

1.Face your fear
Before you resolve any problem you are facing, the first thing is to be realistic and admit that such a problem exists. Acknowledge that it exists, and have faith that you will overcome it. When you become courageous enough to face your fear, then you will overcome it.

2.Be knowledgeable of what you will deliver
It will be of great help to you if you know your material thoroughly, not only memorizing it. You have to have good knowledge of the information you want to pass across, the main message and your key points. To be calm and relaxed on stage, just be prepared.

3.Don’t think it’s all about you
When making a public speech or addressing a crowd, we mostly think that everyone is looking at us, and thus this will make us uncomfortable. Before making a public speech, we need to adjust the way we see things. Change your mindset and know that although everybody in the room is looking at us, in reality, half of them are more interested in the message or content we are delivering, while their own thoughts and other irrelevant things carry the rest away. 

4.Interact with your audience
When addressing the public, a big way to release the tension in you and free yourself from public speaking anxiety is by interacting with your audience. {'count': 5, 'next': None, 'previous': None, 'results': [{'id': 6, 'category': {'id': 7, 'title': 'Psychology', 'categoryDesc': 'Evergreen psychology blogs.', 'categoryImage': 'https://s3.us-west-004.backblazeb2.com/encurate/static/blogsapi/1/Psychology-Psychology.png'}, 'title': 'How to cope up with nightmares', 'body': 'For many people, nightmares are a major barrier to a good night’s sleep. Getting enough sleep is necessary for your body to operate as it should. While the amount of sleep you need differs from person to person, it’s generally recommended that adults get between 7 to 9 hours of sleep a night.  In today’s fast-paced world, it’s common to “get by” on a lot less. Many people are so sleep-deprived, they don’t even notice the effects on their bodies! Some people even brag about how little they sleep, or how they “run on coffee”. 

Sleep is so essential, that not getting enough sleep is correlated to everything from weight gain, to heart disease, weakening of the immune system, distractibility that can lead to increased risk of accidents, and much more. 

Nightmares in adults can be caused by certain types of medication; PTSD, depression, anxiety or sleep disorders; stress and more. 

What can you do when you’re struggling with sleep deprivation due to recurring nightmares?

●Get out of bed. Don’t torture yourself by lying in bed for hours after waking up from a nightmare. If you can’t fall back asleep, get out of bed. Make yourself some chamomile tea, go for a five-minute walk or take a shower. Doing this can give your body and mind a kind of “reset” that will help you fall back asleep quickly. 
●Keep a dream journal. When you wake up from a dream, write down everything you can remember about it. You’ll probably find out common themes that keep showing up in the nightmares. When you identify these themes, you can look closely at your life and deal with the issues.
